newsitem.title: GERMANY: German grain intervention offers sharply down.
newsitem.headline: German grain intervention offers sharply down.

text.p: Sales offers into German grain intervention stores in the Nov-May 1996/97 season by Nov 15 totalled 167,096 tonnes compared with 783,693 tonnes a year earlier, state grain intervention board BLE said on Monday.
The figure described volumes accepted, but not yet delivered to stores, by the close last Friday.

Traders said market prices of grains in most regions were well above the November buying-in level of 231.49 marks per tonne and sellers were hoping for German free market wheat and rye exports to third countries in the near term.
Barley prices were heading closer towards the intervention level because of lacking third country business and competition from an ample domestic maize crop, they added.
BLE gave the following breakdown in tonnes --
